Description.val:
Tactical/Mobile (TacMobile) C4I Systems: The Tactical Mobile program provides evolutionary systems and equipment upgrades to support the Maritime Patrol and Reconnaissance Force Commanders with the capability to plan, direct and control the tactical operations of Maritime Patrol and Reconnaissance Aircraft (MPRA) and other assigned units within their respective area of responsibility. Looking ahead, TacMobile provides critical reach-back capabilities between the Maritime Patrol and Reconnaissance Aircraft, primarily the P-8A/Poseidon, and MQ-4C/Triton, and the Maritime Intelligence Surveillance and Reconnaissance Enterprise. These operations include littoral, open ocean, and over land long-dwell surveillance, anti-surface warfare, over-the-horizon targeting, counter-drug operations, power projection, anti-submarine warfare, mining, search and rescue, indications and warnings, and special operations. The missions are supported by the fixed-site Tactical Operations Centers (TOCs) and Mobile Tactical Operations Centers (MTOCs). Each TacMobile unit is a system-of-systems. TOCs provide sensor and tactical data communications systems; mission planning/mission support, sensor analysis capabilities; avionics and weapons system interfaces, media devices and data handling capabilities, at fixed-site locations. MTOC is a scalable, mobile version of the TOC for contingency operations and for support of MPRA operations from remote forward operating base airfields.

7 TOCs: 6 operational systems (located at Jacksonville Florida, Sigonella Italy, Kaneohe Bay Hawaii, Whidbey Island Washington, Kadena Japan, and Bahrain), and 1 laboratory system (the "TacMobile Systems Integration Lab" (TMSIL), collocated at NIWC Atlantic detachment Patuxent River Maryland with PMA-290's P-8A "Pax River Systems Integration Lab" (PAXSIL)).

15 MTOCs: 10 operational systems (5 systems  home ported at Naval Air Station (NAS) Jacksonville Florida and 5 systems at NAS Whidbey Island Washington), 1 laboratory system (an aircraft integration lab located at Navy Detachment Dallas), 1 C4I engineering and maintenance support system (located at the In Service Engineering Activity (ISEA), NWIC Atlantic), 1 C4I mobile systems schoolhouse (located at the Center for Naval Air Technical Training (CNATT) Jacksonville Florida), and 2 systems undergoing production/integration with C4I equipment procured in FY19, and standalone Mobility/Facilities equipment procured in FY20, to meet current operational configuration/requirements.

The TacMobile program uses an evolutionary development strategy consisting of incremental upgrades to meet new and emergent Fleet requirements, while retaining current capabilities. Increments are planned and resourced to support the MPRF Family of Systems aircraft: P-8A Poseidon aircraft and its upgrades; Advanced Airborne Sensor (AAS); and MQ-4C Triton.

T4050 will fund TacMobile Command, Control, Computer, Communications and Intelligence (C4I), network, and reach back communications systems modernization. Additionally, the line item funds TacMobile interfaces with P-8A (including Advanced Airborne Sensor (AAS)) and MQ-4C aircraft systems and sensors, and tactical communications modernization. Together these separate capabilities are combined to provide the TOCs and MTOCs with an Integrated Warfighting Capability to support Maritime Patrol P-8A operation requirements and pace aircraft modernization requirements.

TacMobile C4I/P-8A modernization are synchronized to provide Technical Refreshes and Incremental Capability upgrades which provide the underlying C4I Infrastructure components and aircraft support capabilities components that ride on the C4I infrastructure. There are five major TacMobile components comprised of currently twenty three distinct subsystems that are developed in synchronization to work together, and are therefore fielded together. New or modernized aircraft interfaces are built specifically to integrate onto the new or modernized C4I infrastructure. They operate together as an overarching system of systems.

Deployable Joint Command and Control (DJC2)(JH500):  DJC2 provides a self-contained, standardized, rapidly deployable, modular, scalable, and reconfigurable joint command and control (C2) capability to designated Geographic Combatant Commands (GCCs). DJC2 is the materiel solution to Defense Planning Guidance that called for the development of standing Joint Task Forces (JTF) with a deployable C2 capability. DJC2 will ensure that Joint Force Commanders (JFC) are equipped, as well as trained and organized to carry out their C2 responsibilities. DJC2 provides GCCs and JFCs a mission critical, integrated family of systems with which to plan, control, coordinate, execute and assess operations. It is designed to deploy rapidly, set up within hours and quickly provide necessary C2 mission and collaboration functionality across the full spectrum of JTF operations. DJC2 has also been deployed in support of Humanitarian Assistance and Disaster Relief (HA/DR) efforts. The capability is intended for all levels of conflict and will be reconfigurable to meet specific GCC and JTF mission requirements. This capability is interoperable with higher and adjacent echelons of command (to include coalition allies), as well as supporting elements to include joint forces. 

DJC2 sites are as follows: six (6) DJC2 core systems garrisoned in Tampa, Florida (1); Brunswick, Georgia (1); Stuttgart, Germany (1); United States Pacific Command (USPACOM), Okinawa, Japan (1) and Pearl Harbor, Hawaii (1); and Navy Europe (NAVEUR), Sigonella, Italy (1).

[P40A / Increment 3 FRP]: Increment capability upgrades include Command and Control, systems and Aircraft Interfaces necessary to support Maritime Patrol Hub and Spoke Expeditionary Capability.  Provides Multiple Domain access, and Cross Domain solutions (UNCLASS / SECRET / TS SCI and SAP,  to support Maritime Patrol Familly of Systems aircraft operations.  P-8A Inc 3 Services Oriented Architecture, Net Enabled Weapons, Anti Submarine Warfare Quick Reaction Capability, as well as other Maritime Patrol Familly of Systems Aircraft Systems.

[P40A / Minotaur / Maven]: Funding procures / Installs Minotaur/Maven capabilities at TOC and MTOC to enhance Processing/Exploitation/Dissemination (PED) automation of P-8A Intelligence/Surveillance/Reconnaissance (ISR) data, improves data persistence, and identification (ID) generation for automated and reduced processing times. Provides enhanced PED and Battlespace Awareness across ISR and non-traditional ISR platforms. Provides post-flight Machine Learning/Artificial Intelligence (ML/AI) to enable post-mission processing of Full Motion Video (FMV) and Acoustic Intelligence (ACINT) for P-8 missions to improve automation and speed of PED operations. Installs Maritime FMV and ACINT algorithms via Maven appliances to classify mission relevant activity data for automatic post mission reporting products. Supports automation of Post-Mission PED within TOC/MTOC in support of Maritime Operations.

[P40A / Shore Pre-Installation and Design]: Increment capability upgrades include Command and Control, systems and Aircraft Interfaces necessary to support Maritime Patrol Hub and Spoke Expeditionary Capability.  Provides Multiple Domain access, and Cross Domain solutions (UNCLASS / SECRET / TS SCI and SAP,  to support Maritime Patrol Familly of Systems aircraft operations.  P-8A Inc 3 Services Oriented Architecture, Net Enabled Weapons, Anti Submarine Warfare Quick Reaction Capability, as well as other Maritime Patrol Familly of Systems Aircraft Systems.

Justification.val:
Overall budget request reduction is due to a decrease in the TacMobile MTOC C4I system procurement, unit cost decrease for DJC2 system enhancements, and the completion of TacMobile Tech Refresh 2.1.1 system procurement.

FY21 request funds the installation of TacMobile TOC and MTOC Technical Refresh and Total Inventory Objective (TIO) MTOC items procured in FY20.

FY21 funding procures Technical Refresh of TacMobile TOC and MTOC C4I and P-8A aircraft interfaces. Specifically TR 2.1.2 procures Technical Refresh of the TacMobile P-8A Aircraft Interface Subsystem (AIS) and the associated P-8A AIS Fly-Away Kit (FAK) to maintain interoperability with the P-8A aircraft. FY21 funding also procures critical Cyber upgrades for the TOC and MTOC C4I Networks, Workstations, and Data Storage environment, to address cybersecurity and extend service life of fielded systems.

FY21 funding supports DJC2 system communication modernization efforts for six (6) sites. DJC2 will maintain interoperability with Joint Force Commanders, address cyber vulnerabilities, and extend service life of fielded systems. Additionally, funds support delivering Next Generation Enclave (NGE) compute and storage resources, Global Broadcast System (GBS) communication, Environmental Control Units (ECUs), and AC2 capability for operations in denied and degraded environments.

Name.@footnote: FY19 OCO funding recieved July '19 / Placed on Contract Sep '19,  7 month procurement lead time, will be installed 3Q/4Q FY20.
Provided overarching technical modernization and technical refresh to fielded TacMobile systems.

Name.val: 2) JH500 DJC2 Increment I System Enhancements

Name.@footnote: Quantities listed represent six (6) Deployable Joint Command and Control (DJC2) core system garrisoned in Tampa, Florida (1); Brunswick, Georgia (1); Stuttgart, Germany (1); USPACOM, Okinawa, Japan (1) and Pearl Harbor, Hawaii (1); and NAVEUR, Sigonella, Italy (1).   Unit costs vary due to the number or level of core system modernization efforts performed at each site from year to year. Unit cost decrease from FY20 to FY21 is due to additional funding in FY20 for procurement of Assured Command and Control (AC2) modems. FY21 funding focuses on delivering Next Generation Enclave (NGE) compute and storage resources, Global Broadcast System (GBS) communication, Environmental Control Units (ECUs), and AC2 capability for operations in denied and degraded environments. Additionally, DJC2 will maintain interoperability with Joint Force Commanders, address cyber vulnerabilities, and extend service life of fielded systems. These improvements reduce size, weight, power requirements, and improves DJC2 cyber posture.

ModificationTitle.val: Tactical Mobile (TacMobile) C4I Systems - Tech Refresh 2.1.1

Title.val: Tactical Mobile (TacMobile) C4I Systems - Tech Refresh 2.1.1

Name.@footnote: For Tactical Operations Center: 1. Quantities represent separate Command & Control & Intelligence (C2I), Communications, Aircraft Interface, and Facility component system upgrades of TacMobile systems.  2. TacMobile Tech Refresh 2.1.1 consists of refreshing 5 major components (made up of 14 individual subsystems) that range in cost from $500K (MIDS JTRS radios) to $1,350K(Higher Than SECRET (HTS) Enclave C2I components). The tech refresh hardware composition is dependent upon the requirements of the site at the time of refresh. In FY19 the primary components procured were HF Radios for the Communications Component and Higher Than SECRET (HTS) Enclave C21 components. FY20 will procure MIDS JTRS radios, Link Monitoring Management Tool, and Tactical Mobile Acoustic Support System (TacMASS) subcomponent refresh. HTS Enclave procurement in FY19 results in significantly higher Average Unit Cost, than the less expensive components being procured in FY20.

For Tactical Operations Center: 1. Quantities represent separate Command & Control & Intelligence (C2I), Communications, Aircraft Interface, and Facility component system upgrades of TacMobile systems.  2. TacMobile Tech Refresh 2.1.1 consists of refreshing 5 major components (made up of 14 individual subsystems) that range in cost from $500K (MIDS JTRS radios) to $1,350K(Higher Than SECRET (HTS) Enclave C2I components). The tech refresh hardware composition is dependent upon the requirements of the site at the time of refresh. In FY19 the primary components procured were HF Radios for the Communications Component and Higher Than SECRET (HTS) Enclave C21 components. FY20 will procure MIDS JTRS radios, Link Monitoring Management Tool, and Tactical Mobile Acoustic Support System (TacMASS) subcomponent refresh. HTS Enclave procurement in FY19 results in significantly higher Average Unit Cost, than the less expensive components being procured in FY20.

ImplementationMethodName.val: [none specified]:: Installation Name: TacMobile C4I Systems Technical Refresh 2.1.2

Description.val: Technical Refresh of Command and Control, Networking and Communications systems necessary to maintain support Maritime Patrol Family of Systems aircraft operations. Includes: Network modernization to maintain Cyber Security posture; Communications  refresh and modernization; Sensor analysis, mission planning, and in-flight mission support capabilities, avionics and weapons system interfaces modernization necessary to support P-8A Operations
